Story: I stared at my phone, my heart pounding. Just minutes ago, I’d seen the message from Jamie—my offhand joke at dinner last night had really stung, and now they were hurt and confused. I knew I had to call, to explain, to apologize before the misunderstanding grew. That’s what friends do: we talk things out, we don’t let silence fester. But as I reached for my phone, the loudspeaker crackled overhead, calling all operators to the mandatory pre-shift briefing. New procedures, they’d said—attendance was non-negotiable, and missing it could mean disciplinary action. My uniform felt tighter, the weight of responsibility pressing down. I glanced at the clock, then at my phone again. Jamie needed me, but so did my job. I could already hear the supervisor’s voice in my head, reminding me of the standards I was expected to uphold. My thumb hovered over Jamie’s contact, my other hand clutching my operator’s badge, torn between the friend who needed my words and the duty that demanded my presence.
